results:
Based on my search results, I can provide you with a comprehensive overview of contemporary literary criticism and academic analysis of Gulliver's Travels, with particular attention to recent approaches from 2020-2025. Here's what I found:

## Contemporary Critical Approaches to Gulliver's Travels (2020-2025)

### Ecocritical Analysis
Recent criticism has explored Swift's "ecocritical" concern with animal issues in relation to humans. Although the animal theme in Gulliver's Travels does involve satirical intentions, scholars argue that it has more profound implications that manifest Swift's forward-looking ideas regarding the relation between humans and their natural environment, as represented in the human-animal relationship. The ethical stand and moral commitment to the natural world represented by animals, and the care for making the themes of a literary work a means to create connections between man and the natural environment around him, are basic ecocritical values that Swift stresses both explicitly and implicitly throughout the novel.(no content)Some recent studies highlight Swift's ecocritical concern with animal issues, focusing on how the behaviour of the noble horses challenges the conventional hierarchies of the anthropocentric view of the world and anticipates values that are prominent in today's society. This article aims to show that what has traditionally challenged and disturbed readers, publishers and critics for many years is the presence of the other race of the animal world, the Yahoos. Analysing the reception of Gulliver's journey to the land of the Houyhnhnms helps understand how Swift's early ecocritical ideas disturbed publishers and translators, who often rejected or modified the text, particularly those passages in which the filthy human-like Yahoos show their harsh and scatological behaviour.

### Feminist Literary Criticism
Recent feminist analysis argues that Gulliver's Travels contains underlining themes of misogyny and patriarchy. Most highlighted in Gulliver's voyage to Brobdingnag (Part II), the themes are showcased in the main protagonist's reflections on women's physical appearance, which show his repulsion and disgust for their flaws. The gigantic size of the Brobdingnagian women allows Gulliver to express his loathing of the opposite gender, as though he is examining them through a looking glass. Furthermore, Gulliver's misogynistic perspective and patriarchal expectations are obvious in him taking offense to women's having a prominent public presence, implying his view of women as being unworthy of such a position.(no content)During Gulliver's trip to Laputa, the emphasis shifts to women's immorality and infidelity, which reflects misogynistic stereotypes and women's sexual objectification. The profound societal differences between the lands of Lilliput, Brobdingnag, and Laputa showcase, nevertheless, existing inequalities between men and women in the 18th century, some of which are still relevant today.

### Cultural and Postcolonial Studies
Contemporary analysis views Gulliver's Travels as "the quintessential example of the dark side of wonder, the side that allows colonial structures to re-commit cognitive genocide through the excessive power of authorial final word." The travel narrative is a genre which by its very nature serves to distance its readers from the very people and cultures it wishes to spotlight. Wonder, in the age of exploration, can be defined simply with this excerpt from Lawrence Weschler's Mr. Wilson's Cabinet of Wonders quoting American literary historian Stephen Greenblatt: "'Wonder,' Greenblatt argues, 'was the central figure in the initial European response to the New World, the decisive emotional and intellectual experience in the presence of radical difference.'"(no content)Critics note how Swift's text demonstrates "the reversal of the gaze" when the King of Brobdingnag responds to Gulliver's description of his home country: "But by what I have gathered from your own relation […] I cannot but conclude the bulk of your natives to be the most pernicious race of little odious vermin that nature ever suffered to crawl upon the surface of the earth." This reversal is extremely relevant to the theme of wonder—wonder that is understood to be a power dynamic between the observer and the observed, or historically between white colonizers and the societies they catalogued. This moment remains a clear directive to the reader to question the unmistakable lack of objectivity of the travel narrative genre, as well as the relevancy of travel texts made.

### Recent Academic Publications (2020-2025)

A 2021 article in SMART MOVES JOURNAL IJELLH analyzed Swift's use of satirical techniques, noting that "Jonathan swift employed literary device called invective, satire in his writing to cure social malaise of seventeenth century society. Gulliver's travels are a political allegory in which seventeenth century society is highlighted in many aspects."(no content)Recent criticism has also examined the concept of "reverse culture shock" in the novel, analyzing "the effects of reverse culture shock on Gulliver's behavior and his interaction with his family through a close reading of the text of Gulliver's Travels. Gulliver who suffers from an obvious identity crisis fails to cope with the readjustment problems at home after living among different hosts. After every subsequent re-entry, Gulliver's behavior especially with his family members deteriorates. The imprints of his last hosts remain so deeply engraved on his mind that fails to live peacefully with his family members and has to live in isolation. This is where we can relate Gulliver to people who after living abroad fail to adjust with the people of their native society and family members."

### Contemporary Relevance and Educational Applications

A 2022 educational analysis explored how "Gulliver's Travels contains a critique of 18th century British education. By following his journey we can examine today's educational values."(no content)Contemporary scholars argue that "Gulliver's Travels is a complex social commentary that manages to retain relevancy in an increasingly homogenized world, thanks to its unfortunately still-pertinent critique of English dominance and literary irresponsibility. Swift's work stuck with me because it offers an explicit critique of English domination and travel prose. The novel speaks to the inescapable European bias of the explorer and the transgressive nature of travel."

### Interdisciplinary Approaches

Contemporary criticism has also examined economic themes in the novel: "Jonathan Swift's masterpiece, Gulliver's Travels, considered at first a children's book, has been for a long time the subject of a debate among philosophers, political scientists, and literary critics. Apart from its keen political satire, Gulliver's Travels approaches in a very non-standard way interesting socioeconomic topics such as the legal system, political science, and colonisation. Moreover, Swift provides interesting insights about human nature and behaviour when describing the nations visited by Captain Gulliver. This paper examines to what extent economic philosophy can contribute to the understanding of Gulliver's Travels, and what economists can learn from Swift's extravagant digressions."

Contemporary academic analysis of Gulliver's Travels continues to find new relevance in the work through various critical lenses including ecocriticism, feminist theory, postcolonial studies, and interdisciplinary approaches that examine its economic, political, and cultural dimensions.
